column1: atha śrīskānde mahāpurāṇe prathamaṃ māheśvarakhaṇḍaṃ prārabhyate | śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ | oṃnamo bhagavate vāsudevāya | oṃnārāyaṇaṃ namaskṛtya naraṃ caiva narottamam | devīṃ sarasvatī caiva tato jayamudīrayet || 1 ||
column2: Obeisance to Śrī Gaṇeśa. Om, obeisance to Lord Vāsudeva. Om. After bowing down to Nārāyaṇa[1] as well as to (Sage) Nara,[2] the most excellent one among men, and to goddess Sarasvatī (the goddess of learning), one should narrate the Jaya.[3]

column1: vyāsa uvāca | yasyājñayā jagatsraṣṭāviriṃciḥ pālako hariḥ | saṃhartā kālarudrākhyo namastasmai pinākine || 1 ||
column2: Vyāsa said: 1. Obeisance to that Lord, the wielder of Pināka bow, at whose bidding Viriñci (Brahmā) creates the universe, Hari (Viṣṇu) protects it and the god named Kālarudra annihilates it.

column1: tīrthānāmuttamaṃ tīrthaṃ kṣetrāṇāṃ kṣetramuttamam | tatraiva naimiṣāraṇye saunakādyāstapodhanāḥ | dīrghasatraṃ prakurvaṃtaḥ satriṇaḥ karmacetasaḥ || 2 ||
column2: 2. There, in the Naimiṣa[5] forest which is the holiest among all holy places and sacred-most among all the sacred spots (in the world), ascetics with Śaunaka[6] as their leader—ascetics who were (usual) performers of sacrifices and whose minds were (always) inclined towards holy rites, started a sacrifice of along duration.

column1: teṣāṃ sadarśanautsukyādāgato hi mahātapāḥ | vyāsaśiṣyo mahāprājño lomaśonāma nāmataḥ || 3 ||
column2: 3. The excessively (highly) intelligent disciple of Vyāsa, an ascetic of great austerities, named Lomaśa[7], came there with an ardent desire to see them.

column1: tatrāgataṃ te dadṛśurmunayo dīrghasatriṇaḥ | uttasthuryugapatsarve sārghyahastāḥ samutsukāḥ || 4 ||
column2: 4. As soon as they saw him coming, all the sages engaged in that sacrifice of long duration, stood up simultaneously with great eagerness to receive him, with materials of worship in their hands.

column1: dattvārghyapādyaṃ satkṛtya munayo vītakalmaṣāḥ | taṃ papracchurmahābhāgāḥ śivadharmaṃ savistaram || 5 ||
column2: 5. After offering him water for washing his feet and presenting him respectfully materials of worship the sinless sages received him with due hospitality. The sages of exalted nobility then asked him to explain in detail Śivadharma (pious activities pertaining to Śiva).

column1: ṛṣaya ūcuḥ | kathayasva mahāprājña devadevasya śūlinaḥ | mahimānaṃ mahābhāga dhyānārcanasamanvitam || 6 ||
column2: The sages said: 6. Recount, O sage of extraordinary intellect, the greatness of the Trident-bearing Lord of Devas. O exalted one, describe everything along with the modes of meditation and worship.

column1: pradāne ca vitānasya tathā dhārāgṛhasya ca | dīpadāne kiṃ phalaṃ syātpūjāyāṃ kiṃ phalaṃ bhavet || 8 || kānikāni ca puṇyāni kathyatāṃ śivapūjane | itihāsapurāṇāni vedādhyayanameva ca || 9 || śivasyāgre prakurvaṃti kārayantyatha vā narāḥ | kiṃ phalaṃ ca nṛṇāṃ teṣāṃ kathyatāṃ vistareṇa hi || 10 ||
column2: 7-11. What is the benefit in sweeping (the temple premises)? What is the benefit in making (mystic diagrams) of various colours, in making gifts of mirror, chowries etc. (or in offering these to Śiva), in constructing canopies as well as fountains? What will be the benefit in offering lamps? What will be the fruit of the worship? What are the meritorious results in worshipping Śiva? Men read and recite the Itihāsas and Purāṇas in front of the idol of Śiva. They study (recite) the Vedas in front of him, and make others do the same. What benefit do those men derive? Let it be mentioned in detail. There is no one else in the world, O sage, more devoted to the narratives about Śiva.

column1: iti śrutvā vacasteṣāṃ munīnāṃ bhāvitātmanām | uvāca vyāsaśiṣyo'sau śivamāhātmyamuttamam || 12 ||
column2: 12. On hearing these words of those sages of sanctified souls, the disciple of Vyāsa recounted (to them) the excellent greatness of Śiva. Lomaśa said:

column1: lomaśa uvāca | aṣṭādaśapurāṇeṣu gīyate vai paraḥ śivaḥ | tasmācchivasya māhātmyaṃ vaktuṃ ko'pi na pāryate || 13 ||
column2: 13. In all the eighteen Purāṇas, Śiva is sung about as the greatest (lord). Hence no one is competent to recount the greatness of Śiva (adequately).

column1: śiveti dvyakṣaraṃ nāma vyāhariiṣyaṃti ye janāḥ | teṣāṃ svargaśca mokṣaśca bhaviṣyati na cānyathā || 14 ||
column2: 14. Heaven and liberation (from Saṃsāra) will be attained by those people who repeatedly utter the two-syllabled name Śi-va.[8] Not otherwise.

column1: udāro hi mahādevo devānāṃ patiriśvaraḥ | yena sarvaṃ pradattaṃ hi tasmātsarva iti smṛtaḥ || 15 ||
column2: 15. Munificent indeed is Mahādeva, (the great god), the lord of Devas, the Supreme Ruler. Since everything has been given by him, he is named Sarva.

column1: te dhanyāste mahātmāno ye bhajaṃti sadā śivam || 16 || vinā sadāśivaṃ yohi saṃsāraṃ tartumicchati | sa mūḍho hi mahāpāpaḥ śivadveṣī na saṃśayaḥ || 17 || bhakṣitaṃ hi garaṃ yena dakṣayajño vināśitaḥ | kālasya dahanaṃ yena kṛtaṃ rājñaḥ pramocanam || 18 ||
column2: 16-18. Blessed are they, noble-souled are they, who always worship Śiva (or the ever-auspicious god). A person who wishes to cross (the ocean) of worldly existence without Sadāśiva, is indeed foolish and confounded. There is no doubt that he, the hater of Śiva, is a great sinner. It was by him that (Halāhala) poison was swallowed, Dakṣa’s sacrifice was destroyed, Kāla (god of Death) was burnt down and the king was released.

column1: ṛṣaya ūcuḥ | yathā garaṃ bhakṣitaṃ ca yathā yajño vināśitaḥ | dakṣasya ca tathā brūhi paraṃ kautūhalaṃ hi naḥ || 19 ||
column2: The sages requested: 19. We are very eager. Recount unto us how the poison was swallowed and how Dakṣa’s Yajña (sacrifice) was destroyed.

column1: sūta uvāca | dākṣāyaṇī purā dattā śaṃkarāya mahātmane | vacanādbrahmaṇo viprā dakṣeṇa parameṣṭhinaḥ || 20 ||
column2: Sūta narrated: 20. Formerly at the instance of Brahmā Parameṣṭhin, Dākṣāyaṇī (Dakṣa’s daughter) was given (in marriage) to noble-souled Śaṅkara by Dakṣa, O brāhmaṇas.

column1: ekadā hi sa dakṣo vai naimiṣāraṇyamāgataḥ | yadṛcchāvaśamāpanna ṛṣibhiḥ paripūjitaḥ || 21 || stutibhiḥ praṇipātaiśca tathā sarvaiḥ surāsuraiḥ | tatra sthito mahādevo nābhyutthānābhivādane | cakārāsya tataḥ kruddho dakṣo vacanabravīt || 22 ||
column2: 21-22. Once, by chance, Dakṣa came to the Naimiṣa forest. On arrival, he was duly honoured by the sages as well as by all Suras and Asuras by means of eulogies and obeisances. Mahādeva who was present there, did not stand up nor did he offer any reverential salutation to him. Therefore, Dakṣa became furious and he spoke these words:

column1: sarvatra sarve hi surāsurā bhṛśaṃ namaṃti māṃ vipravarāḥ samutsukāḥ | kathaṃ hyasau durjanavanmahātmā bhūtādibhiḥ pretapiśācayuktaḥ | śmaśānavāsī nirapatrapo hyayaṃ kathaṃ praṇāmaṃ na karoti me'dhunā || 23 ||
column2: 23. “Everywhere all the Suras and Asuras as well as excellent brāhmaṇas repeatedly bow down to me with great eagerness. How is it, then, that, like a vicious fellow, this noble-souled one does not pay obeisance to me now. Accompanied by vampires, goblins and others, he is a shameless permanent resident of the cremation ground.

column1: pākhaṃḍino durjanāḥ pāpaśīlā vipraṃ dṛṣṭvā coddhatā unmadāśca | vadhyāstyājyāḥ sadbhirevaṃvidhā hi tasmādenaṃ śāpituṃ codyato'smi || 24 ||
column2: 24. Heretics, wicked people and habitual sinners become haughty and arrogant on seeing a brāhmaṇa. Indeed, people like these deserve killing of excommunication by good people. Hence I am intent on cursing him.”

column1: ityevamuktvā sa mahātapāstadā ruṣānvito rudramidaṃ babhāṣe || 25 ||
column2: 25-27. After saying thus that (Dakṣa) of great austerities, became angry and spoke to Rudra these words:

column1: śrṛṇvaṃtvamī vipratamā idānīṃ vaco hi me kartumihārhathaitat | rudro hyayaṃ yajñabāhyo vṛto me varṇātīto varṇaparo yataśca || 26 ||
column2: “May these excellent brāhmaṇas listen to these words of mine. It behoves you all to carry out my words. This Rudra is considered by me as banned out of all Yajñas because he has gone beyond the Varṇas (castes) and has transgressed the discipline of the Varṇas.”

column1: naṃdī niśamya tadvākyaṃ śailādo hi ruṣānvitaḥ | abravīttvarito dakṣaṃ śāpadaṃ taṃ mahāprabham || 27 ||
column2: Nandin, son of Śilāda, became furious on hearing those words. He promptly said to Dakṣa who had great refulgence but who uttered that curse: Nandin said:

column1: yajño dānaṃ tapaścaiva tīrthāni vividhāni ca | yasya nāmnā pavitrāṇi soyaṃ śapto'dhunā katham || 29 || vṛthā te brahmacāpalyācchapto'yaṃ dakṣa durmate | yenedaṃ pālitaṃ viśvaṃ sarveṇa ca mahātmanā | śapto'yaṃ sa kathaṃ pāpa rudro'yaṃ brāhmaṇādhama || 30 ||
column2: 28-30. Why is my lord Maheśa excluded from Yajñas? Merely by remembering him all these Yajñas become fruitful. Sacrifice, charitable gift, penance, different kinds of holy spots of pilgrimage—all these became sanctified by his name. Why has he been cursed now? He has been cursed by you foolishly and improperly due to your brāhmaṇical rashness, O evil-minded Dakṣa. It is by the noble-souled Śarva that this universe is protected. How is it that Rudra has been cursed, O sinful base brāhmaṇa?

column1: evaṃ nirbhārtsitastena naṃdinā hi prajāpatiḥ | naṃdinaṃ ca śaśāpātha dakṣo roṣasamanvitaḥ || 31 ||
column2: 31. On being rebuked thus by Nandin, Dakṣa, the Prajā-pati, became furious and he cursed Nandin:

column1: yūyaṃ sarve rudravarā vedabāhyāśca vai bhṛśam | śaptāhi vedamārgaiśca tathā tyaktā maharṣibhiḥ || 32 || pāṣaṃḍavādasaṃyuktāḥ śiṣṭa'cārabahiṣkṛtāḥ | kapālinaḥ pānaratāstathā kālamukhā hyamī || 33 ||
column2: 32-33. “All of you devoted to Rudra have been completely excluded from the Vedas. You are indeed cursed by the followers of the Vedic path and excommunicated by the great sages. You all ding to heretical doctrines. You are out of the pale of refined breeding and good conduct. All these Kapālins (followers of the skull-cult) are black-faced and addicted to drinking liquor.”[9]

column1: iti śaptāstadā tena dakṣeṇa śivakiṃkarāḥ | tadā prakupito naṃdī dakṣaṃ śaptuṃ pracakrame || 34 ||
column2: 34. Thus the servants of Śiva were then cursed by Dakṣa. Then the infuriated Nandin began to imprecate Dakṣa:

column1: śaptā vayaṃ tvayā vipra sādhavaḥ śivakiṃkarāḥ | vṛthaiva brahmacāpalyādahaṃ śāpaṃ dadāmi te || 35 ||
column2: 35. “O brāhmaṇa, although we, the servants of Śiva, are good and pious, we have been cursed by you improperly (and unnecessarily) out of your brāhmaṇical rashness. Now I shall curse you.

column1: vedavādaratā yūyaṃ nānyadastītivādinaḥ | kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā lobhamohasamanvitāḥ || 36 || vaidikaṃ ca puraskṛtya brāhmaṇāḥ śūdrayājakāḥ | daridriṇo bhaviṣyaṃti pratigraharatāḥ sadā || 37 ||
column2: 36-39. Arguing that there is nothing else you all adhere to Vedic doctrines. (But) you are lustful, desirous of heaven, greedy and deluded. Keeping a follower of the Vedas in front, brāhma-ṇas will perform sacrifices on behalf of Śūdras. They will always be impoverished and greedy of monetary gifts. O Dakṣa, some brāhmaṇas will become brahmarākṣasas (brahminical demons).” Lomaśa said:

column1: dakṣa kecidbhaviṣyanti brāhmaṇā brahmarākṣasāḥ | lomaśa uvāca | viprāste śapitāstena naṃdinā kopinā bhṛśam || 38 ||
column2: Those brāhmaṇas were (thus) cursed by Nandin who had become excessively angry.

column1: athākarṇyeśvaro vākyaṃ naṃdinaḥ prahasanniva | uvāca vākyaṃ madhuraṃ bodhayayuktaṃ sadāśivaḥ || 39 ||
column2: On hearing the words of Nandin, Sadāśiva smilingly spoke these sweet enlightening words:

column1: mahādeva uvāca | kopaṃ nārhasi vai kartuṃ brāhmaṇānprati vai sadā | brāhmaṇāguravo hyete vedavādaratāḥ sadā || 40 ||
column2: Mahādeva said: 40. It does not behove you to be angry always towards brāhmaṇas. These brāhmaṇas, devoted to Vedic doctrines, are always our elders and preceptors.

column1: vedo maṃtramayaḥ sākṣāttathā sūktamayo bhṛśam | sūkte pratiṣṭhito hyātmā sarveṣāmapi dehinām || 41 ||
column2: 41. The Vedas are full of mantras and of sūktas (hymns). The ātman of every embodied being is established in the hymn.

column1: tasmānnātmavido nindyā ātmaivāhaṃ na cetaraḥ | ko'yaṃ kastvaṃ kva cāhaṃ vai kasmācchaptā hi vai dvijāḥ || 42 || prapaṃcaracanāṃ hitvā buddho bhava mahāmate | tattvajñānena nirvartya svasthaḥ krodhādivarjitaḥ || 43 ||
column2: 42-43. Hence those who have realized the ātman should not be censured. I am the ātman myself, no one else. Who is this? Who are you? Where am I? Why are the brāhmaṇas cursed? Avoid the concept of diversity, O highly intelligent one, and become enlightened. Manage (everything) through the knowledge of reality. Be established in your own self and avoid anger etc.

column1: evaṃ prabodhitastena śaṃbhunā parameṣṭhinā | vivekaparamo bhūtvā śailādo hi mahātapāḥ | śivena saha saṃgamya paramānaṃdasaṃplutaḥ || 44 ||
column2: 44. On being advised and instructed thus by Śaṃbḥu, the Supreme Being, Nandin (Śilāda’s son) of great austerities, became aware of true knowledge and discernment. Closely associating himself with Śiva, he became immersed in (the ocean of) great bliss.

column1: dakṣopi hi ruṣā'viṣṭaṛṣibhiḥ parivāritaḥ | yayau sthānaṃ svakaṃ tatra praviveśa ruṣā'nvitaḥ || 45 ||
column2: 45. Overwhelmed by anger, Dakṣa went to his abode accompanied by the sages. He entered his abode still indignant.

column1: śraddhāṃ vihāya paramāṃ śivapūjakānāṃ niṃdāparaḥ sa hi babhūva narādhamaśca | sarvairmaharṣibhirupetya sa tatra śarvaṃ devaṃ nininda na babhūva kadāpi śāntaḥ || 46 ||
column2: 46. Abandoning his great faith in those who worship Śiva and engaged in censuring them, he became the basest of men. Reaching that place along with all the great sages, he continued to censure lord Śiva. He never became calm. FOOTNOTES AND REFERENCES: Nārāyaṇa—It is significant that a Purāṇa specifically compiled for the glorification of Śi va begins with an obeisance to Nārāyaṇa.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | ekadā tu tadā tena yajñaḥ prāraṃbhito mahān | tatrāhūtāstadā sarve dīkṣitena tapasvinā || 1 ||
column2: The prejudice against Kāpālikas is found even in classical Sanskrit literature.[Sanskrit text for this chapter is available] Lomaśa said: 1. Once, a great sacrifice was commenced by him (Dakṣa). All were invited to be present there by the ascetic (Dakṣa) (who was) initiated for the sacrifice.

column1: ṛṣayo vividhāstatra vaśiṣṭhādyāḥ samāgatāḥ | agastyaḥ kaśyapo'triśca vāmadevastathā bhṛguḥ || 2 || dadhīco bhagavānvyāso bharadvājo'tha gautamaḥ | ete cānye ca bahavaḥ samājagmurmaharṣayaḥ || 3 ||
column2: 2-3. A number of sages including Vasiṣṭha and others came there. Agastya, Kaśyapa, Atri, Vāmadeva, Bhṛgu, Dadhīca, holy lord Vyāsa, Bharadvāja and Gautama, these and many other great sages assembled there.

column1: tathā sarve suragaṇā lokapālastathā'pare vidyādharāśca gaṃdharvāḥ kiṃnarāpsarasāṃ gaṇāḥ || 4 ||
column2: 4. Similarly all the groups of Suras (gods), the Guardians of the Quarters and others, Vidyādharas, Gandharvas, Kinnaras and groups of celestial damsels (came there).

column1: saptalokātsamānīto brahmā lokapitāmahaḥ | vaikuṃṭhācca tathā viṣṇuḥ samānīto maravaṃ prati || 5 ||
column2: 5. Brahmā, the grandfather of worlds, was invited from Satyaloka. Similarly Viṣṇu was invited from Vaikuṇṭha to the place of sacrifice.

column1: devendro hi samānīta iṃdrāṇyā saha suprabhaḥ | tathā caṃdro hi rohiṇyā varuṇaḥ priyayayā saha || 6 ||
column2: 6. Devendra of great lustre came along with Indrāṇī. Similarly the Moon-god came along with Rohiṇī and Varuṇa came in the company of his beloved.

column1: kuberaḥ puṣpakārūḍho mṛgā'rūḍho'tha mārutaḥ | bastā'rūḍhaḥ pāvakaśca pretā'rūḍho'tha nirṛti || 7 ||
column2: 7. Kubera came there riding in his aerial chariot Puṣpaka, Wind-god riding on his deer, Fire-god riding on his goat and Nirṛti riding on a ghost.

column1: ete sarve samāyātā yajñavāṭe dvijanmanaḥ | te sarve satkṛtāstena dakṣeṇa ca durātmanā || 8 ||
column2: 8. All these came to the sacrificial enclosure of the Brāhmaṇa. All of them were received and honoured by the evil-minded Dakṣa.

column1: bhavanāni mahārhāṇi suprabhāṇi mahāṃti ca | tvaṣṭrā kṛtāni divyāni kauśalyena mahātmanā || 9 ||
column2: 9. Great and divine abodes of great value and good splendour were skilfully constructed by the noble-souled Tvaṣṭṛ.

column1: teṣu sarveṣu dhiṣṇyeṣu yathājoṣaṃ samāsthitāḥ || 10 ||
column2: 10-13. (The visitors) occupied all those abodes according to their pleasure.

column1: varttamāne mahāyajñe tīrthe kanakhale tathā | ṛtvijaśca kṛtāstena bhṛgvādyāśca tapodhanāḥ || 11 || dīkṣāyuktastadā dakṣaḥ kṛtakautukamaṃgalaḥ | bhāryayā sahito vipraiḥ kṛtasvatyayano bhṛśam || 12 || reje mahattvena tadā suhṛdbhiḥ paritaḥ sadā | etasminnaṃtare tatra dadhīcirvākyamabravīt || 13 ||
column2: When the great sacrifice commenced in the holy spot Kanakhala,[1] the ascetics beginning with Bhṛgu were appointed as Ṛtviks by him. Then Dakṣa underwent due initiation. The solemn, auspicious ceremony was duly performed. Benedictory rites were completed by the Brāhmaṇas for the sake of Dakṣa accompanied by his wife. Always surrounded by his friends, he shone remarkably, thanks to his greatness. In the meantime, Dadhīci spoke these words there:

column1: dadhīciruvāca | ete sureśā ṛṣayo mahattarāḥ salokapālāśca samāgatāstava | tathā'pi yajñastu na śobhate bhṛśaṃpinākinā tena mahātmanā vinā || 14 ||
column2: Dadhīci said: 14. These leading Suras (gods), the great sages and the Guardians of the Quarters have come to your (sacrifice). Still the Yajña does not shine properly without (the presence of) the noble-souled Pināka-bearing Lord.

column1: yenaiva sarvāṇyapi maṃgalāni jātāni śaṃsaṃti mahāvipaścitaḥ | so'sau na dṛṣṭo'tra pumānpurāṇo vṛṣadhvajo nīlakaṇṭhaḥ kapardī || 15 ||
column2: 15. Great learned men say that everything becomes auspicious and splendid through him. That primordial Puruṣa (person), the bull-bannered, blue-throated lord with matted hair, is not seen here.

column1: amaṃgalānyeva ca maṃgalāni bhavaṃti yenādhikṛtāni dakṣa | triyaṃbakenātha sumaṃgalāni bhavaṃti sadyohyapamaṃgalāni || 16 ||
column2: 16. Presided over and authorized by him, O Dakṣa, even inauspicious things become auspicious. (Without) the Three-eyed Lord, very auspicious things become instantly bereft of their auspiciousness.

column1: sarvaireva hi gaṃtavyaṃ yatra devo maheśvaraḥ || 18 || dākṣāyaṇyā sametaṃ tamānayadhvaṃ tvarānvitāḥ | tena sarvaṃ pavitraṃ syācchaṃbhunā yoginā bhṛśam || 19 || yasya smṛtyā ca nāmoktyā samagraṃ sukṛtaṃ bhavet | tasmātsarvaprayatnena samāneyo vṛṣadhvajaḥ || 20 ||
column2: 17-20. Hence he must be invited only by you immediately through Braḥmā, Viṣṇu the powerful lord and Śakra. All of them should go where lord Maheśvara is present. Bring him along with Dākṣāyaṇī. Hurry up. Everything shall become extremely sanctified through that Yogin Śaṃbhu by remembering whom and by uttering whose names, merits become well-accomplished. Hence, with all your efforts, the Bull-bannered Lord should be brought.

column1: tasya tadvacanaṃ śrutvā prahasannāha duṣṭadhīḥ | mūlaṃ viṣṇurhi devānāṃ yatra dharmaḥ sanātanaḥ || 21 || yasminvedāśca yajñāśca karmāṇivividhāni ca | pratiṣṭhitāni sarvāṇi so'sau viṣṇurihāgataḥ || 22 ||
column2: 21-26. On hearing these words of his, the evil-minded (Dakṣa) said laughing (derisively): “Indeed the root cause of Devas is Viṣṇu in whom the eternal virtue (Dharma) is present. In him Vedas, Yajñas and the different kinds of holy rites are established and that Viṣṇu has come here.

column1: satyalokātsamāyāto brahmā lokapitāmahaḥ | vedaiścopaniṣadbhiśca āgamairvividhaiḥ saha || 23 ||
column2: Brahmā, the grandfather of the worlds, has come from Satyaloka along with the Vedas, Upaniṣads and various kinds of Āgamas (scriptural treatises).

column1: tathā suragaṇaiḥ sākamāgataḥ surarāṭ svayam | tathā yūyaṃ samāyātā ṛṣayo vītakalmaṣāḥ || 24 ||
column2: Similarly the king of Suras (gods) himself has come along with the groups of Suras. So also you, the sinless sages, have come.

column1: yeye yajñocitāḥ śāṃtāstete sarve samāgatāḥ | vedavedārthatattvajñāḥ sarve yūyaṃ dṛḍhavratāḥ || 25 ||
column2: All those tranquil ones who are worthy (of being present) in a Yajña have come. All of you are conversant with the Vedas, Vedic expositions and reality. All of you are steadfast in your holy rites and observances.

column1: atraiva ca kimasmākaṃ rudreṇāpi prayojanam | kanyā dattā mayā viprā brahmaṇā noditena hi || 26 ||
column2: Of what avail is Rudra to us in this matter? Of course, my daughter has been given to him by me, O Brāhmaṇa, (but that was) when I had been urged by Brahmā.

column1: akulīno hyasau viprā naṣṭo naṣṭapriyaḥ sadā | bhūtapretapiśācānāṃ patireko duratyayaḥ || 27 ||
column2: 27. He is not of noble birth, O Brāhmaṇa. He is doomed and he is always a favourite of the doomed. He is the sole lord of goblins, ghosts and vampires. He is unfathomable.

column1: ātmasaṃbhāvito mūḍhaḥstabdho maunī samatsaraḥ | karmaṇyasminnayogyo'sau nānīto hi mayā'dhunā || 28 ||
column2: 28. He esteems himself very much. He is deluded and stubborn. He is tacitern, jealous and malicious. In this holy rite he is utterly unworthy. Hence indeed he was not invited by me now.

column1: tasmāttvayā na vaktavyaṃ punarevaṃ vacodvija | sarvairbhavadbhiḥ kartavyo yajño me saphalo mahān || 29 ||
column2: 29. Hence, words like these should not be uttered by you again, O Brāhmaṇa. My great Yajña should be made successful by all of you collectively.”

column1: etacchrutvā vacastasya dadhīcirvākyamabravīt || 30 ||
column2: 30. On hearing these words of his, Dadhīci made the following statement:

column1: dadhīciruvāca | sarveṣāmṛṣivaryāṇāṃ surāṇāṃ bhāvitātmanām | anayo'yaṃ mahāñjāto vinā tena mahātmanā || 31 ||
column2: Dadhīci said: 31. Great injustice has been done to all these excellent sages and Devas of sanctified soul by not having the noble soul with them.

column1: vināśo'pi mahānsadyohyatratyānāṃ bhaviṣyati | evamuktvā dadhīco'sāveka eva vinirgataḥ || 32 ||
column2: 32-33. A great ruin will soon befall all those who are present here.

column1: yajñavāṭācca dakṣasya tvaritaḥ svāśramaṃ yayau | munau vinirgate dakṣaḥ prahasannidamabravīt || 33 ||
column2: After saying thus, Dadhīci alone walked out in protest from the sacrificial enclosure of Dakṣa and hurriedly went to his hermitage. When the sage went out, Dakṣa said this laughingly:

column1: gataḥ śivapriyo vīro dadhīcirnāma nāmataḥ | āviṣṭacittā maṃdāśca mithyāvādaratāḥ khalāḥ || 34 ||
column2: 34-36. “There, a heroic supporter and friend of Śiva named Dadhīci, has gone out. All those slow-witted rogues whose minds are possessed by evil spirits, who are enamoured of heretic doctrines, who are excluded from the Vedas and whose behaviour and acts are vicious, should leave this holy rite.

column1: vedabāhya durācārāstyājyāste hyatra karmaṇi | vedavādaratā yūyaṃ sarve viṣṇupurogamāḥ || 35 ||
column2: You are all devoted to Vedic doctrines having Viṣṇu as your leader. O Brāhmaṇas, make my Yajña fruitful ere long.”

column1: yajñaṃ me saphalaṃ viprāḥ kurvaṃtu hyacirādiva | tadā te devayajanaṃ cakruḥ sarve saharṣayaḥ || 36 ||
column2: Then all of them along with the sages performed the worship of the lord.

column1: etasminnaṃtare tatra parvate gaṃdhamādane | dhārāgṛhe vimānena sakhībhiḥ parivāritā || 37 || dākṣāyaṇī mahādevī cakāra vividhāstadā | krīḍā vimānamadhyastā kandukādyāḥ sahasraśaḥ || 38 ||
column2: 37-40. In the meantime there on the mountain Gandhamādana[3] the great goddess Dākṣāyaṇī was engaged in various kinds of sports. She was surrounded by her female friends. Sometimes she played beneath in the Dhārāgṛha (chamber fitted with fountains and water-jets). Sometimes she moved about in an aerial chariot- Sometimes she stood in the middle of the aerial chariot and indulged in thousands of sports with balls etc.

column1: krīḍāsaktā tadā devī dadarśātha mahāsatī | yajñaṃ prayāṃtaṃ somaṃ ca rohiṇyā sahitaṃ prabhum || 39 ||
column2: While engaged in playing the games, the great goddess Satī saw the Moon-god going to the place of sacrifice along with Rohiṇī.

column1: kva gamiṣyati caṃdro'yaṃ vijaye pṛccha satvaram | tayoktā vijayā devī taṃ papraccha yathocitam || 40 ||
column2: She said to her maid Vijayā, “Where is Candra going now? O Vijayā, go and enquire immediately.” On being thus instructed by her, the gentle lady Vijayā asked him suitably.

column1: kathitaṃ tena tatsarvaṃ dakṣasyaiva makhādikam | tacchrutvā tvaritā devī vijayā jātasaṃbhramā | kathayāmāsa tatsarvaṃ yaduktaṃ śaśinā bhṛśam || 41 ||
column2: 41. Everything about Dakṣa’s sacrifice and other things were told by him. On hearing it the gentle lady Vijayā became agitated. Hurriedly (she went to Satī) and told her everything exactly as it was said by the Moon-god.

column1: vimṛśya kāraṇaṃ devī kimāhvānaṃ karoti na | dakṣaḥ pitā me mātā ca vismṛtā māṃ kuto'dhunā || 42 || pṛcchāmi śaṃkaraṃ cādya kāraṇaṃ kṛtaniścayā | sthāpayitvā sakhīstatra āgatā śaṃkaraṃ prati || 43 ||
column2: 42-43. The goddess began to ponder over the reason thus: ‘Why does he not invite (us)? Dakṣa is my father. Why has my mother forgotten me now? I shall ask Śaṅkara now about the reason (thereof).’ After deciding thus, she asked the friends to stay there and approached Śaṅkara.

column1: dadarśataṃ sabhāmadhye trilocanamavasthitam | gaṇaiḥ parivṛtaṃ sarvaiścaṃḍamuṃḍādibhistadā || 44 || bāṇo bhṛṃgistathā naṃdī śailādo hi mahātapāḥ | mahākālo mahācaṃḍo mahāmuṃḍo mahāśirāḥ || 45 || dhūmrākṣo dhūmraketuśca dhūmrapādastathaiva ca | ete cānye ca bahavo gaṇā rudrānuvartinaḥ || 46 ||
column2: 44-49. She saw the Three-eyed Lord in the centre of the assembly stationed there, in an extremely wonderful seat, and surrounded by all his Gaṇas (attendants) beginning with Caṇḍa and Muṇḍa, Bāṇa, Bhṛṅgin, Nandin of great power of penance, the son of Śilāda, Mahākāla, Mahācaṇḍa. Mahāmuṇḍa, Mahāśiras, Dhūmrākṣa, Dhūmraketu and Dhūmrapāda—these and many other Gaṇas, the followers of Rudra, (were present there). Some were hideous and terrifying. Others were mere headless trunks. Some had no eyes. Others were devoid of chests. There were hundreds like these. All of them had elephant-hides for their clothes. Clusters of matted hair were their ornaments. All were adorned with Rudrākṣa beads. They were devoid of attachment, They had conquered their sense-organs. They, were antagonistic to objects of sensual pleasure. Śaṅkara, the benefactor of the worlds, was seen by her surrounded by all these.

column1: ākṣiptacittā sahasā jagāma śivasaṃnidhim | śivena sthāpitā svāṃke prītiyuktena vallabhā || 50 || premṇoditā vacobhiḥ sā bahumānapuraḥsaram | kimāgamanakāryaṃme vada śīghraṃ sumadhyame || 51 ||
column2: 50-52. Bewildered in her mind, she suddenly went to Śiva’s presence. The beloved wife was placed in his lap by Śiva who was pleased. She was addressed with loving words with due respect: “O lady of excellent waistline, what is the purpose of your arrival? Tell me quickly.”

column1: evamuktā tadā tena uvācāsitalocanā || 52 ||
column2: On being spoken thus by him, the dark-eyed lady said:

column1: satyuvāca | piturmama mahāyajñe kasmāttava na rocate | gamanaṃ devadevaśa tatsarvaṃ kathaya prabho || 53 ||
column2: Satī said: 53. O lord, O lord of the chiefs of Devas, how is it that going to the great sacrifice of my father is not approved of by you? Tell (me) everything.

column1: suhṛdāmeṣa vai dharmaḥ suhṛdbhiḥ saha saṃgatim | kurvaṃti yanmahādeva suhṛdāṃ prītivardhinīm || 54 || tasamātsarvaprayatnena anāhūto'pi gaccha bhoḥ | yajñavāṭaṃ piturme'dya vacanānme sadāśiva || 55 ||
column2: 54-55. This is the duty of friends, O Mahādeva, that they (regularly) associate with their friends, thereby increasing the pleasure and love of their friends. Hence make all efforts (to be present there). Oh, go there even if you have not been invited. Go to the sacrificial enclosure of my father today at my request, O Sadāśiva.

column1: tasyāstadvacanaṃ śrutvā ba bhāṣe sūnṛtaṃ vacaḥ | tvayā bhadre na gaṃtavyaṃ dakṣasya yajanaṃ prati || 56 ||
column2: 56-57. On hearing her words (Śiva) spoke these kind and sincere words:

column1: tasya ye māninaḥ sarve sasurāsukiṃnarāḥ | te sreva yajanaṃ prāptāḥ pitustava na saṃśayaḥ || 57 ||
column2: “O gentle lady, you must not go to the sacrifice of Dakṣa. All those persons who honour Dakṣa, including Suras, Asuras and Kinnaras, have undoubtedly gone to the sacrifice of your father.

column1: anāhūtāśca ye subhru gacchaṃti paramandiram | apamānaṃ prāpnuvanti maraṇādadhikaṃ tataḥ || 58 || pareṣāṃ maṃdiraṃ prāpta iṃdropi laghutāṃ vrajet | tasmāttvāyā na gaṃtavyaṃ dakṣasya yajanaṃ śubhe || 59 ||
column2: 58-59. O lady of fine eyebrows, those who go to others’ mansions without being invited, meet with insult which is more (painful) than death. Even Indra who goes to the abode of others meets with contempt and disrespect. Hence, O splendid lady, you must not go to Dakṣa’s sacrifice.”

column1: evamuktā satī tena maheśena mahātmanā | uvāca roṣasaṃyuktaṃ vākyaṃ vākyavidāṃ varā || 60 ||
column2: 60. On being told thus by the noble-souled Śiva, Satī, the most excellent one among those who are conversant with modes of expression, spoke these words full of anger:

column1: yajño hi satyaṃ loke tvaṃ sa tvaṃ devavareśvara | anāhūto'si tenādya pitrā me dṛṣṭacāriṇā | tatsarvaṃ jñātumicchāmi tasya bhāvaṃ durātmanaḥ || 61 ||
column2: 61. “It is true that you are (the real) Yajña in this world, O most excellent lord of Devas. (How is it) that you have not been invited by my father of evil conduct today? Hence I wish to know thoroughly the attitude of that evil-minded one.

column1: tasmāccādyaiva gacchāmi yajñavāḍaṃ piturmmama | anujñāṃ dehi me nātha devadeva jagatpate || 62 ||
column2: 62. Hence I shall go to the sacrificial enclosure of my father today itself. Grant me permission, O my lord, lord of the universe, lord of Devas.”

column1: ityukto bhagavānrudrastayā devyā śivaḥ svayam | vijñātākhiladṛgdraṣṭā bhagavānbhūtabhāvanaḥ || 63 ||
column2: 63-65a. On being told thus by that goddess, Lord Śiva himself, who has knowledge and vision of everything, the lord who is the sanctifier of all living beings, the lord of Devas, Maheśa, the bestower of all Siddhis said to her:

column1: sa tāmuvāca deveśo maheśaḥ sarvasiddhidaḥ | gaccha devi tvarāyuktā vacanānmama suvrate || 64 ||
column2: “Go quickly, O gentle lady of holy rites, at my instance, riding on this Nandin and accompanied by various kinds of Gaṇas.”

column1: etaṃ naṃdinamāruhya nānāvidhagaṇānvitā | gaṇāḥ ṣaṣṭisahasrāṇi jagmūraudrāḥ śivajñayā || 65 || tairgaṇaiḥ saṃvṛtā devī jagāma pitṛmaṃdiram | nirīkṣya tadbalaṃ sarvaṃ mahādevotivismitaḥ || 66 || bhūṣaṇāni mahārhāṇi tebhyo devyai paraṃtapaḥ | preṣayāmāsa cāvyagro mahādevo'nu pṛṣṭhataḥ || 67 ||
column2: 65b-68. At the bidding of Śiva, sixty thousand of the terrifying Gaṇas went (along with her). Surrounded by those Gaṇas, the goddess went to the abode of her father. Observing the entire army, Mahādeva became excessively surprised. Mahādeva, the unperturbed scorcher of enemies, sent very valuable ornaments to her through his attendants. He sent them immediately after her.

column1: devyā gataṃ vai svapiturgṛhaṃ tadā vimṛśya sarvaṃ bhagavānmaheśaḥ | dākṣāyaṇī pitravamānitā satī na yāsyatīti svapuraṃ punarjagau || 68 ||
column2: Pondering over the departure of the goddess to her father’s abode, Lord Maheśa exclaimed: “On being insulted by her father, Satī, the daughter of Dakṣa, will never come back to her city again.”

column1: iti śrīskāṃde mahāpurāṇa ekāśītisāhasryāṃ saṃhitāyāṃ prathame māheśvarakhaṇḍe kedārakhaṃḍe dakṣayajñaṃ prati satīdevyāgamanavarṇanaṃnāma dvitīyo'dhyāyaḥ || 2 ||
column2: Kanakhala—A village two miles to the east of Haridwar (U.P.), at the junction of Gaṅgā and Nīladhārā.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | dākṣāyaṇī gatā tatra yatra yajño mahānabhūt | tatpituḥ sadanaṃ gatvā nā nāścaryasamanvitam || 1 || dvāri sthitā tadā devā avatīrya nijāsanāt | naṃdino hi mahābhāgā devalokaṃ nirīkṣya ca || 2 || mātaraṃ pitaraṃ dṛṣṭvā suhṛtsaṃbaṃdhi vāṃdhavān | abhivādyaiva pirataṃ mātaraṃ ca mudānvitā || 3 ||
column2: 1-4a. Dākṣāyaṇī went to the place where the great sacrifice was being performed. After going to the abode of her father, the abode which was full of various wonderful things, she stood at the entrance. The Devas of exalted fortune became delighted. They got down from their seats. After seeing the congregation of the Devas, her parents, friends, relatives and kinsmen, she made obeisance to her father and mother with delight. Then the goddess spoke these words in a manner suitable to the occasion:

column1: śaṃbhunā hi vinā tāta kathaṃ yajñaḥ pravartate | ete kathaṃ samāyātā brahmaṇā sahitāḥ pitaḥ || 7 || he bhṛgo tvaṃ na jānāsi he kaśyapa mahāmate | atre viśiṣṭha ekastvaṃ śakra kiṃ kṛtamadyate || 8 || he viṣṇo tvaṃ mahādevaṃ jānāsi parameśvaram | brahmankiṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi mahādevasya vikramam || 9 ||
column2: 4b-9. “Why was Śaṃbḥu, the extremely splendid (lord), not invited by you? (He is the lord) by whom this entire universe consisting of the mobile and immobile beings has been sanctified. He is Yajña (incarnate), an (important) part of Yajña, the sacrificial gift offered therein, the material offered therein, the Mantras etc., the Havya and Kavya—he is identical with all these things. He is the most excellent one among those who are expert in performing Yajñas. Everything performed without him will become impure. How can a sacrifice function (at all), O dear father, without Śaṃbhu? How did these come here, O father, along with Brahmā? Don’t you know? O Bhṛgu, O Kaśyapa of great intellect, O Atri, O Vasiṣṭha? You are alone, O Śakra, what has been done by you today? O Viṣṇu, you do know the supreme lord Mahādeva. O Brahmā, don’t you know the valour of Mahādeva?

column1: purā paṃcamukho bhūtvā garvitosi sadāśivam | kṛtaścaturmukhastena vismṛto'si tadadbhutam || 10 ||
column2: 10. Formerly you happened to be five-faced. You (spoke) arrogantly to Sadāśiva and you were made four-faced. It is surprising that you have forgotten that miracle.

column1: bhikṣāṭanaṃ kṛtaṃ yena purā dāruvane vibhuḥ | śaptoyaṃ bhikṣuko rudro bhavadbhiḥ sakhibhistadā || 11 ||
column2: 11. He is the lord Rudra who formerly begged for alms in the forest of Dāruvana,[1] when this mendicant was cursed by you (and) your friends.

column1: śaptenāpi ca rudreṇa bhavadbhirvismṛtaṃ katham | yasyāvayavamātreṇa pūritaṃ sacarācaram || 12 || liṃgabhūtaṃ jagatsarvaṃ jātaṃ tatkṣaṇameva hi | layānālliṃgamityāhuḥ sarve devāḥ savāsavāḥ || 13 || sarve devāśca saṃbhūtā yato devasya śūlinaḥ | so'sau vedāṃtago devastvayā jñātuṃ na pāryate || 14 ||
column2: 12-14. Even after cursing Rudra, how was (this incident) forgotten by you? He is the lord by whose limb alone the universe including the mobile and immobile beings, has been filled up. The entire universe became the Liṅga at that very instant. They call it Liṅga because of the dissolution (of the universe in it).[2] All the Devas along with Vāsava (Indra) are born of the Trident-bearing Lord. Such a lord who is to be realized through the Vedāntas, cannot be comprehended by you.”

column1: tasyā vacanamākarṇya dakṣaḥ kruddho'bravīdvacaḥ | kiṃ tvayā bahunoktena kāryaṃ nāstīha sāṃpratam || 15 ||
column2: 15-19a. On hearing her words, Dakṣa became angry and spoke these words:

column1: gaccha vā tiṣṭhavā bhadre kasmāttvaṃ hi samāgatā | amaṃgalo hi bhartā te aśivosau sumadhyame || 16 ||
column2: “Of what avail is your verbal prolixity. It has no relevance to the present occasion. O gentle lady, (you may) go or stay. Why did you come at all? Your husband is an inauspicious fellow, not conducive to propitiousness, O lady of good waistline.

column1: akulīno vedabāhyo bhūtapretapiśācarāṭ | tasmānnākārito bhadre yajñārthaṃ cārubhāṣiṇi || 17 ||
column2: He is ignoble, excluded from the Vedas. He is the king of goblins, ghosts and vampires. Hence he was not invited to the sacrifice, O gentle lady of sweet speech.

column1: mayā dattāsi suśroṇi pāpinā maṃdabuddhinā | rudrāyāviditārthāya uddhatāya durātmane || 18 || tasmātkāyaṃ parityajya svasthā bhava śucismite | dakṣeṇoktā tadā putrī sā satī lokapūjitā || 19 ||
column2: O lady of excellent loins, it is to Rudra who is haughty and evil-minded and of unknown antecedents that you had been given in marriage by me, a dull-witted sinner. Hence, abandon this body (of yours), O lady of pure smiles, and be happy.” 19b-23. It was thus that his own daughter Satī who was worshipped by all the worlds, was addressed by Dakṣa then.

column1: niṃdāyuktaṃ svapitaraṃ vilokya ruṣitā bhṛśam | ciṃtayaṃtī tadā devī kathaṃ yāsyāmi maṃdire || 20 || śaṃkaraṃ draṣṭukāmāṃha kiṃ vakṣye tena pṛcchitā | yo niṃdati mahādevaṃ niṃdyamānaṃ śrṛṇoti yaḥ | tāvubhau narake yāto yāvaccandradivākarau || 21 || tasmāttayakṣyāmyahaṃ dehaṃ pravekṣyāmi hutāśanam || 22 ||
column2: On seeing her own father full of contempt (for Śiva), Satī became excessively furious. Then the goddess thought thus: ‘Though I am desirous of seeing Śaṅkara, how can I go back to our mansion? What will I say if I am asked (about this incident) by him? He who censures Mahādeva and he who listens when Mahādeva is being censured—both of them go to hell and remain there as long as the moon and the sun (shine). Hence I will abandon this body and enter fire.’ Pondering thus and being overwhelmed by insult, she entered fire[3] uttering the words “O Rudra, O Śiva”.

column1: hāhākāreṇa mahatā vyāptamāsīddigaṃtaram | sarve te maṃcamārūḍhāḥ śastrairvyāptā niraṃtarāḥ || 24 || śastraiḥ svairjadhnurātmānaṃ svāni dehāni cicchiduḥ | kecitkaratale gṛhya śirāṃsi svāni cotsukāḥ || 25 ||
column2: 24-30. The entire quarters became pervaded with the great uproar of “Alas! Alas!”. All those (who had come with Satī) climbed on to the platform. Laden with weapons they crowded the place without any gap. They hit and struck themselves with their weapons. They cut off their own bodies. Some of them cut off their heads and eagerly performed the Nīrājana (waving of the lights in circles) rites with them. Immediately they were reduced to ash. Then everyone said thus: “Twenty thousand of the Gaṇas roared terrifically. Those dreadful ones cut off their limbs by means of weapons. Thus they all perished there along with Dākṣāyaṇī.”[4]

column1: gaṇāstatrāyūte dve ca tadadbhutamivābhavat | te sarva ṛṣayo devā iṃdrādyāḥ samarudgaṇāḥ || 28 || viśve'śvanau lokapālāstūṣṇīṃbūtāstadābhavan | viṣṇuṃ vareṇyaṃ kecicca prārthayaṃtaḥ samaṃtataḥ || 29 || evaṃ bhūtastadā yajño jātastasya durātmanaḥ | dakṣasya brahmabaṃdhośca ṛṣayo bhayamāgatāḥ || 30 ||
column2: That was a great miracle. All sages, the Devas beginning with Indra, along with the groups of Maruts, Viśvedevas, Aśvins and the Guardians of the Quarters—all these became silent then. Some of them (walked) round requesting Viṣṇu, the most excellent one. This was the end of the Yajña of that evil-minded one. The Yajña of the unworthy Brāhmaṇa Dakṣa (was ruined) and the sages became afraid.

column1: etasminnaṃtare viprā nāradena mahātmanā | kathitaṃ sarvamevaitaddakṣasya ca viceṣṭitam || 31 ||
column2: 31. In the meantime, O Brāhmaṇas, all these activities and behaviour of Dakṣa were communicated to Rudra by the noble-minded Nārada.

column1: tadākarṇyeśvaro vākyaṃ nāradasya mukhodgatam | cukopa paramaṃ kruddha āsanādutpatanniva || 32 ||
column2: 32. On hearing Nārada’s report the supreme Lord Śiva became extremely infuriated. In his anger he as if jumped up from his seat.

column1: uddhṛtya ca jaṭāṃ rudro lokasaṃhārakārakaḥ | āsphoṭayāmāsa ruṣā parvatasya śiropari || 33 ||
column2: 33. Uprooting a plait of hair from his (matted hair), Rudra, the cause of the annihilation of all the worlds, angrily dashed it on the top of the mountain.

column1: tāḍanācca samudbhūto vīrabhadro mahāyaśāḥ | tathā kālī samutpannā bhūtakoṭibhirāvṛtā || 34 ||
column2: 34. As a result of this dashing, Vīrabhadra of great fame rose up. So also did Kālī surrounded by crores of spirits and goblins.

column1: kopānniḥśvasitenaiva rudrasya ca mahātmanaḥ | jātaṃ jvarāṇāṃ ca śataṃ sannipātāstrayodaśa || 35 ||
column2: 35. Through the wrathful breath of the noble-minded Rudra a hundred (types of) Fevers and thirteen Sannipātas (combined derangement of all the three humours causing deadly varieties of fevers) rose up.

column1: vijñapto vīrabhadreṇa rudro raudraparākramaḥ | kiṃ kāryaṃ bhavataḥ kāryaṃ śīghrameva vada prabho || 36 ||
column2: 36. Rudra of fierce and dreadful exploits was entreated by Vīrabhadra “O Lord! what task of Your Lordship is to be carried out? Tell me quickly.”

column1: ityukto bhagavānrudraḥ preṣayāmāsa satvaram | gaccha vīra mahā bāho dakṣayajñaṃ vināśaya || 37 ||
column2: 37. On being requested thus, lord Rudra hurriedly commissioned him, “Destroy Dakṣa’s Yajña.”

column1: śāsanaṃ śirasā dhṛtvā devadevasya śūlinaḥ | kālikā'lihito vīraḥ sarvabhūtaiḥ samāvṛtaḥ | vīrabhadro mahātejā yayau dakṣamakhaṃ prati || 38 ||
column2: 38. Receiving the behest of the Trident-bearing Lord of Devas with his head (i.e. humbly accepting the order), the heroic Vīrabhadra of excessive refulgence, who was kissed (ā-līḍhā) by Kālikā and was surrounded by all goblins rushed to Dakṣa’s sacrifice.

column1: tadānīmeva sahasā durnimittāni cābhavan | rūkṣo vavau tadā vāyuḥ śarkarābhiḥ samāvṛtaḥ || 39 || asṛgvarṣati devaśca timireṇā'vṛtā divaśaḥ | ulkāpātāśca bahavaḥ petururvyāṃ sahasraśaḥ || 40 ||
column2: 39-40. At that very time, ill-omens occurred suddenly. A rough wind blew carrying with it gravels and sand. The Rain-god showered blood. The quarters were enveloped in darkness. Thousands of meteors fell on the earth.

column1: evaṃvidhānyariṣṭāni dadṛśurvibudhādayaḥ | dakṣo'pi bhayamāpanno viṣṇuṃ śaraṇamāyayau || 41 ||
column2: 41. The Devas and others saw such phenomena foreboding evil. Becoming frightened, Dakṣa sought refuge in Viṣṇu.

column1: rakṣarakṣa mahāviṣṇo tvaṃ hi naḥ paramo guruḥ | yajño'si tvaṃ suraśreṣṭha bhayānmāṃ parimocaya || 42 ||
column2: 42. “Save me, save me, O great Viṣṇu. Indeed you are our greatest preceptor and elderly one. You are (identical with) Yajña, O most excellent one among Suras. Save me from this fearful danger,”

column1: dakṣeṇa prārthya māno hi jagāda madhusūdanaḥ | mayā rakṣā vidātavyā bhavato nātra saṃśayaḥ || 43 ||
column2: 43. On being requested and prayed to by Dakṣa, the slayer of Madhu (Viṣṇu) said: “Protection should be accorded to you by me. There is no doubt about it.

column1: apūjyā yatra pūjyaṃte pūjanīyo na pūjyate | trīṇī tatra pravartaṃte durbhikṣaṃ tvayā dharmamajānatāḥ | īśvarāvajñayā sarvaṃ viphalaṃ ca bhaviṣyati || 44 ||
column2: 44. Disrespect has been shown by you, O Dakṣa, without understanding genuine Dharma (Virtue). Due to the contemptuous disregard of Lord Śiva, everything will become fruitless.

column1: apūjyā yatra pūjyaṃ te pūjanīyo na pūjyate | trīṇī tatra pravartaṃte durbhikṣaṃ maraṇaṃ bhayam || 45 ||
column2: 45. Where those who are not worthy of respect are worshipped, where he who is worthy of being worshipped is not worshipped, three consequences, viz. famine, death and fear, prevail there.

column1: tasmātsarvaprayatnena mānanīyo vṛṣadhvajaḥ | amānitānmaheśāttvāṃ mahadbhayamupasthitam || 46 ||
column2: 46. Hence, the Bull-bannered Lord (Śiva) should be honoured with all efforts. Great fear and danger beset you because the great lord was not honoured.

column1: adhunaiva vayaṃ sarve prabhavo na bhavāmahe | bhavato durnnayeneva nātra kāryā vicāraṇā || 47 ||
column2: 47. All of us are not powerful enough now, because of your evil behaviour. There is no need to discuss this matter further.”

column1: viṣṇostadvacanaṃ śrutvā dakṣaściṃtāparo'bhavat | vivirṇavadano bhūtvā tūṣṇīmāsīdbhuvi sthitaḥ || 48 ||
column2: 48. On hearing those words of Viṣṇu, Dakṣa became lost in (anxious) thoughts. Turning pale in the face, he remained silent and sat on the ground.

column1: vīrabhadro mahābāhū rudreṇaiva pracoditaḥ | kālī kātyāyanīśānā cāmuṃḍā muṃḍamarddinī || 49 || bhadrakālī tathā bhadrā tvaritā vaiṣṇavī tathā | navadurgādisahito bhūtānāṃ ca gaṇo mahān || 50 || śākinī ḍākinī caiva bhūtapramathaguhyakāḥ | tathaiva yoginīcakraṃ catuḥ ṣaṣṭyā samanvitam || 51 ||
column2: 49-51. Expressly commanded by Rudra himself the extremely powerful Vīrabhadra came to the sacrificial enclosure accompanied by the nine Durgās and others.[5] The nine Durgās were Kālī, Kātyāyanī, Īśānā, Cāmuṇḍā, Muṇḍamardinī, Bhadrakālī, Bhadrā, Tvaritā and Vaiṣṇavī. A big multitude of Bhūtas also entered the sacrificial enclosure of great refulgence. Śākinīs, Ḍākinīs, Bhūtas, Pramathas, Guhyakas, a host of Yoginīs (in circular formation) along with the sixty-four (Tantras)[6]—all these entered the sacrificial enclosure suddenly.

column1: pārṣadāḥ śaṃkarasyaite sarve rudrasvarūpiṇaḥ | paṃcavaktrā nīlakaṃṭhāḥ sarve te śastrapāṇayaḥ || 53 || chatracāmarasaṃvītāḥ sarve haraparākramāḥ | daśabāhavastrinetrā jaṭilā rudrabhūṣaṇāḥ || 54 || ardhacaṃdradharāḥ sarve sarve caiva mahaujasaḥ | sarve te vṛṣabhārūḍhāḥ sarve te veṣabhūṣaṇāḥ || 55 ||
column2: 52-55. Hundreds and thousands of Gaṇas who accompanied Vīrabhadra were all the Pārṣadas (attendants) of Śaṅkara. All of them had the form of Rudra. They had five faces and blue throats. All had weapons in their hands. They were duly served with umbrellas and chowries. All were as valorous as Śiva. They had ten arms and three eyes. Their hair was matted. They wore the ornaments of Rudra. Bearing crescent moon (on their heads), all of them had (different kinds of) robes and ornaments.

column1: sahasrabāhurbhujagādhipairvṛtastrilocano bhīmabalo bhayāvahaḥ | ebhiḥ sametaśca tadā mahātmā sa vīrabhadro'bhijagāma yajñam || 56 ||
column2: 56. Accompanied by these, the noble-souled, three-eyed, dreadful Vīrabhadra of terrible might, who had a thousand arms and was entwined by great serpents, marched towards the sacrifice.

column1: yugyānāṃ ca sahasreṇa dvipramāṇena syaṃdanam | siṃhānāṃ prayutenaiva vāhyamānaṃ ca tasya tat || 57 ||
column2: 57. His chariot was drawn by two thousand horses and a million lions.

column1: tathaiva daṃśitāḥ siṃhā bahavaḥ pārśvarakṣakāḥ | śārdūlā makarā matsyā gajāścaiva sahasraśaḥ | chatrāṇi vividhānyeva cāmarāṇi tathaiva ca || 58 ||
column2: 58-59a. The armoured defenders of his sides were many lions, tigers, sharks, fishes and thousands of elephants. He had different kinds of umbrellas and chowries held over the head of everyone everywhere.

column1: mūrddhanidhriyamāṇāni sarvatogrāṇi sarvaśaḥ | tato bherīmahānādāḥ śaṃkhāśca vividhasvanāḥ | paṭahā gomukhāścaiva śrṛṃgāṇi vividhāni ca || 59 ||
column2: 59bc. Then high sounding Bherīs (war-drums), conchs of various (degrees of) sounds, Paṭahas (kettle-drums), musical instruments like Gomukka, different kinds of horns were sounded.

column1: tato'vādyaṃta tānyeva ghanāni suṣirāṇi ca | kalagānaparāḥ sarve sarve mṛdaṃgavādinaḥ || 60 ||
column2: 60. Cymbals, gongs and wind instruments were played. All of them were engaged in singing pleasantly. All of them played on Mṛdaṅgas (special drums).

column1: anekalāsyasaṃyuktā vīrabhadrāgratobhavan | raṇavāditranirghoṣairjagarjuramitaujasaḥ || 61 ||
column2: 61. The Gaṇas proceeded ahead in front of Vīrabhadra indulging in different kinds of dances. Those Gaṇas of unmeasured power and potency roared along with the martial sounds of the musical instruments.

column1: tena nādena mahatā nāditaṃ bhuvanatrayam | evaṃ sarve samāyātā gaṇā rudrapraṇoditāḥ || 62 || yajñavāṭaṃ ca dakṣasya vināśārthaṃ prahāriṇaḥ | rajasā cā'vṛtaṃ vyoma tamasā ca vṛtā diśaḥ || 63 ||
column2: 62-63a. By that great sound the three worlds echoed and reverberated. Thus all those Gaṇas ordered (urged) by Rudra came there to the sacrificial enclosure of Dakṣa and began to smash for the sake of destroying it.

column1: saptadvīpavatī pṛthvī cacāla sādrikānanā | te dṛṣṭvā mahadāścaryyaṃ lokakṣayakaraṃ tadā || 64 ||
column2: 63b-64a. The sky was covered with dust and all the quarters were enveloped in darkness. The earth consisting of the seven islands (continents)[7] shook along with the mountains and forests.

column1: uttasthuryugapatsarve devadaityaniśācarāḥ | te vai dadṛśurāyāṃtīṃ rudrasenā bhayāvahām || 65 ||
column2: 64b-65. Those Devas, Daityas and night-wanderers observed this wonderful spectacle foreboding the ruin of all the worlds. Ail of them stood up simultaneously. They saw the dreadful army of Rudra advancing.

column1: pṛthvīṃ kecitsamāyātā gagane kecidāgatāḥ | diśaśca pradiśaścaiva samāvṛtya tathāpare || 66 || anaṃtā hyakṣayāḥ sarve śūrā rudrasamā yudhi | evaṃbhūtaṃ ca tatsainyaṃ rudraiśca parivāritam | dṛṣṭvo curvismitāḥ sarve yāmo'dya śastrapāṇayaḥ || 67 ||
column2: 66-67. Some of them were coming over the earth. Some were coming through the sky. Others covered the quarters and the intervening spaces and rushed on. All of them were of inexhaustible strength; infinite (in number), they were heroic on a par with Rudra in battle. On seeing such an army surrounded by (the followers of) Rudra, alī of them said in great surprise and dismay: “Let us advance (against them) with weapons in the hands.”

column1: iṃdro hi gajamārūḍho mṛgārūḍhaḥ sadāgatiḥ | yamo mahiṣamārūḍho yamadaṃḍasamanvitaḥ || 68 || kuberaḥ puṣpakārūḍhaḥ pāśī makarameva ca | agnirbastamārūḍho nirṛtiḥ pretameva ca || 69 || tathānye surasaṃghāśca yakṣacāraṇaguhyakāḥ | āruhya vāhanānyeva svānisvāni pratipinaḥ || 70 ||
column2: 68-70. Indra rode on his elephant. The Wind-god rode on a deer. Yama equipped with the rod of death rode on a buffalo. Kubera drove in the aerial chariot Puṣpaka. Varuṇa rode on a shark. The Fire-god rode on a goat. Nirṛti rode on a ghost. Similarly other groups of Suras, Yakṣas, Cāraṇas and Guhyakas, valorously rode on their respective vehicles.

column1: sveṣāmudyogamālokya dakṣaścāśrumukhastataḥ | daṃḍavatpatito bhūmau sarvānevābhyabhāṣata || 71 ||
column2: 71. On seeing the preparations of his own people, Dakṣa’s face was covered with tears. He prostrated himself on the ground and spoke to all of them:

column1: yuṣmadbalenaiva mayā yajñaḥ prāraṃbhito mahān | satkarmasiddhaye yūyaṃ pramāṇaṃ sumahāprabhāḥ || 72 ||
column2: 72. “O (friends) of great lustre, it was on the strength of your support that this great Yajña was begun by me. For the accomplishment of this good rite, you are the final authority.

column1: viṣṇo tvaṃ karmaṇaḥ sākṣādyajñānāṃ paripālakaḥ | dharmasya vedagarbhasya brahmaṇyastvaṃ ca mādhava || 73 ||
column2: 73. O Viṣṇu, you are the protector of holy rites and Yajñas as well as the virtue described in the Vedas. O Mādhava, you are the promoter of Brāhmaṇa’s rites.

column1: tasmādrakṣā vidhātavyā yajñasyā'sya mahāprabho | dakṣasya vacanaṃ śrutvā uvāca madhusūdanaḥ || 74 ||
column2: 74. Hence, O great Lord, proper protection should be accorded to this Yajña.” On hearing the words of Dakṣa, the slayer of Madhu (Viṣṇu) replied:[8]

column1: mayā rakṣā vidhātavyā dharmasya paripālane | tatsatyaṃ tu tvayoktaṃ hi kiṃ tu tasya vyatikramaḥ || 75 || yātastvadyaiva yajñasya yattvayoktaṃ sadāśivam | naimiṣe'nimiṣakṣetre tadā kiṃ na smṛtaṃ tvayā || 76 ||
column2: 75-76. “When you say that protection should be accorded by me to maintain holy rites, it is true. But the transgression is of your own doing in regard to this Yajña. You said something to Sadāśiva in the Naimiṣa forest, the holy spot of Devas. Is it not remembered by you?

column1: yo'yaṃ rudro mahātejā yajñarūpaḥ sadāśivaḥ | yajñabāhyaḥ kṛto mūḍha tacca durmmatritaṃ tava || 77 || rudrakopācca ko hyatra samartho rakṣaṇe tava | na paśyāmi ca taṃ vipra tvāṃ vai rakṣati durmmatim || 78 ||
column2: 77-78. Rudra, Sadāśiva, who has great splendour, who is of the form of Yajña, was [excluded from the Yajñas, O deluded one. That was the wrong advice of yours. Who is competent to protect you from Rudra’s wrath? I do not see anyone, O Brāhmaṇa, who can protect you, the evil-minded one.

column1: kiṃ karmma kimakarmmeti tanna paśyasi durmmate | samarthaṃ kevalaṃ karmana bhaviṣyati sarvadā || 79 ||
column2: 79. You do not distinguish between good and evil acts, O evil-minded one. A holy rite alone is not (necessarily) efficacious always (to produce results).

column1: seśvaraṃ karma viddhyotatsamarthatvena jāyate | na hyanyaḥ karmmaṇo dātā īśvareṇa vinā bhavet || 80 ||
column2: 80. Understand that a holy rite with the support of Īśvara (Śiva) is competent to produce results. Excepting Īśvara, there is no other bestower of the fruit of Karman (a holy rite).

column1: īśvarasya ca ye bhaktāḥ śāṃtāstadgatamānasāḥ | karmmaṇo hi phalaṃ teṣāṃ prayacchati sadāśivaḥ || 81 ||
column2: 81. Sadāśiva grants the benefit of the holy rites of those persons who are the devotees of Īśvara, who are calm and whose minds dwell on him.

column1: kevalaṃ karma cāśritya nirīśvaraparā janāḥ | nirayaṃ te ca gacchaṃti koṭiyajñaśatairapi || 82 ||
column2: 82. Those people who solely depend upon Karman and are engaged in denying Īśvara, go to hell even if they perform hundred crores of Yajñas.

column1: punaḥ karmamayaiḥ pāśairbaddhā janmanijanmani | nirayeṣu prapacyaṃte kevalaṃ karmmarūpiṇaḥ || 83 ||
column2: 83. Those who put faith in the Karmans alone are bound by the fetters of Karman in birth after birth. They are roasted and cooked in the hells.” FOOTNOTES AND REFERENCES:

column1: iti śrīskāṃde mahāpurāṇa ekāśītisāhasryāṃ saṃhitāyāṃ prathame māheśvarakhaṇḍe kedārakhaṃḍe vīrabhadraprādurbhāvavarṇanaṃnāma tṛtīyo'dhyāyaḥ || 3 ||
column2: The author of the Purāṇa takes every opportunity to reduce the gulf between Śaivism and Vaiṣṇavism and to assert the oneness of Śiva and Viṣṇu. Viṣṇu’s reply is thus remarkable.[Sanskrit text for this chapter is available]

column1: lomaśa uvāca | viṣṇunoktaṃ vacaḥ śrutvā dakṣo vacanamabravīt | vedānāmapramāṇaṃ ca kṛtaṃ te madhusūdana || 1 ||
column2: Lomaśa said: 1. On hearing the words uttered by Viṣṇu, Dakṣa spoke these words: “O slayer of Madhu (Viṣṇu), you have made it appear that Vedas are not authoritative (pramāṇa).[1]

column1: vaidikaṃ karma cotsṛjya kathaṃ seśvaratāṃ vrajet | taducyatāṃ mahāviṣṇo yena dharmaḥ pratiṣṭhitaḥ || 2 ||
column2: 2. How can one forsake the Vedic rite and accept the doctrine of the authoritativeness of Īśvara? Let this be explained, O Mahāviṣṇu, by whom Dharma has been established?”

column1: dakṣeṇokto mahāviṣṇuruvāca parisāṃtvayan | traigaṇyaviṣayā vedāḥ saṃbhavaṃti na cānyathā || 3 || vedoditāni karmāṇi īśvareṇa vinā katham | saphalāni bhaviṣyaṃti viphalānyeva tāni ca || 4 ||
column2: 3-5. On being asked by Dakṣa, Mahāviṣṇu said to him consolingly: “The Vedas have the three Guṇas for their object.[2] They cannot be otherwise. How can the rites mentioned in the Vedas become fruitful without Īśvara? They definitely become fruitless. Hence seek refuge in Īśvara by all means.”

column1: tasmātsarvaprayatnena īśvaraṃ śaraṇaṃ vraaijā | evaṃ bruvati govinda āgataḥ sainyasāgaraḥ | vīrabhadreṇa sadṛśo dadṛśustaṃ tadā surāḥ || 5 ||
column2: Even as Govinda (Viṣṇu) was saying thus, the ocean of an army, similar to Vīrabhadra’s came there. All the Suras (Devas) saw it.

column1: iṃdropi prahasanviṣṇumātmavādarataṃ tadā | vajrapāṇiḥ suraiḥ sārddhaṃ yoddhukāmo'bhavattadā || 6 ||
column2: 6. Indra laughed at Viṣṇu,who was engaged in explaining the doctrine of Ātman then. With the Vajra (thunderbolt) in his hand, he became desirous of fighting, accompanied by the Suras.

column1: bhṛguṇācāritaḥ śīghramuccāṭanapareṇa hi | tadā gaṇāḥ suraiḥ sārdhaṃ yuyudhuste gaṇānvitāḥ || 7 ||
column2: 7. He was made to go hurriedly by Bhṛgu who was bent upon routing (the Gaṇas). Then, the Gaṇas in the formation of groups fought with the Suras.

column1: śaratomaranāgacairjaghnuste ca parasparam | neduḥśaṃkhāśca bahuśastasminraṇamahotsave || 8 ||
column2: 8. They struck one another with arrows, iron clubs and sharp-pointed missiles. In the course of that great festival of war, many conchs were blown.

column1: tathā dundubhayo neduḥ paṭahā ḍiṃḍimādayaḥ | tena śabdena mahatāślāghyamānāstadā surāḥ | lokapālaiśca sahitā jaghnustāñchivakiṃkarān || 9 ||
column2: 9. So also drums like Dundubhis, Paṭahas, Diṇḍimas etc., were sounded. Thanks to that great sound, the.Suras considered themselves flattered. Accompanied by the Guardians of the Quarters, they killed the servants of Śiva.

column1: khaḍgaiścāpi hatāḥ kecidgadābhiśca vipothitāḥ | devaiḥ parājitāḥ sarve gaṇāḥ śatasahasraśaḥ || 10 ||
column2: 10. Some were killed by means of swords. Some were smashed by means of iron clubs. All of the hundreds and thousands of the Gaṇas were entirely routed by the Devas.

column1: iṃdrādyaurlokapālaiśca gaṇāste ca parāṅgamukhāḥ | kṛtāśca tatkṣaṇādeva bhṛgormaṃtrabalena hi || 11 ||
column2: 11. It was by the power of the Mantras of Bhṛgu, that those Gaṇas were instantaneously defeated and driven back by the Guardians of the Quarters headed by Indra.

column1: uccāṭanaṃ kṛtaṃ teṣāṃ bhṛguṇā yajvinā tadā | yajanārthaṃ ca devānāṃ tuṣṭyarthaṃ dīkṣitasya ca || 12 ||
column2: 12. Their extermination was effected by Bhṛgu who performed the Yāga as the fire-worshipper. He was initiated in this for the sake of the worship, on behalf of the Devas and for their pleasure too.

column1: tenaiva devā jayino jātāstatkṣaṇameva hi | svānāṃ parājayaṃ dṛṣṭvā vīrabhadro rupānvitaḥ || 13 ||
column2: 13. By that alone did the Devas become victorious at the very instant. On seeing the defeat of his own army, Vīrabhadra became angry.

column1: bhūtānpretānpiśācāṃśca kṛtvā tāneva pṛṣṭhataḥ | vṛṣabhasthānpuraskṛtya svayaṃ caiva mahābalaḥ | tīkṣṇaṃ triśūlamādāya pātayāmāsa tānraṇe || 14 || devānyakṣānpiśācāṃśca guhyakānrākṣasāṃ stathā | śūlaghātaiśca te sarve gaṇā devānprajaghnire || 15 ||
column2: 14-15. He made the goblins, ghosts and vampires go to the rear and the bull-riders advance at the front. The leader of great strength took up a sharp trident and struck down the Devas, Yakṣas, Piśācas, Guḥyakas and Rākṣasas in the battle. Striking with spears, all the Gaṇas began to kill the Devas.

column1: keciddvidhākṛtāḥ khaṅgairmudgaraiścāpi pothitāḥ | paraśvadhaiḥ khaṃḍaśaśca kṛtāḥ kecidraṇājire || 16 ||
column2: 16. Some of them were split into two by means of swords. They were smashed with iron clubs. In the course of the battle, some were cut into pieces with battle-axes.

column1: śūlairbhinnāśca śataśaḥ kecicca śakalīkṛtāḥ | evaṃ parājitāḥ sarve palāyanaparāyaṇāḥ || 17 ||
column2: 17. Hundreds were pierced with spears; some were torn to pieces. Thus, all of those being defeated, began to run away.

column1: parasparaṃ pariṣvajya gatāstepi triviṣṭapam | kevalaṃ lokapālāśca iṃdrādyāstasthurutsukāḥ | bṛhaspatiṃ pṛcchamānāḥ kutosmākaṃ jayo bhavet || 18 ||
column2: 18. Embracing each other, they went back to heaven. Only the guardians of the worlds led by Indra remained there, eager (to fight). They consulted Bṛhaspati, “How can we have victory?”

column1: bṛhaspatiruvācedaṃ sureṃdraṃ tvaritastadā | bṛhaspatiruvāca | yaduktaṃ viṣṇunā pūrvaṃ tatsatyaṃ jātamadya vai || 19 ||
column2: 19-22. Bṛhaspati immediately replied to Indra thus: Bṛhaspati said: What had been spoken by Viṣṇu formerly has become true today.

column1: asti cedīśvaraḥ kaścitphalarūpyasya karmmaṇaḥ | kartāraṃ bhajate sopi na hyakartuḥ prabhurhisaḥ || 20 || na maṃtrauṣadhayaḥ sarve nābhicārā na laukikāḥ | na karmāṇi na vedāśca na mīmāṃsādvayaṃ tathā || 21 || jñātumīśāḥ saṃbhavaṃti bhaktyājñeyastvananyayā | śāṃtyā ca parayā tṛṣṭyā jñātavyo hi sadāśivaḥ || 22 ||
column2: If there is īśvara as (bestower of) the benefit of a holy rite, he assigns it (the benefit) to the performer (of the rite). He is not powerful over one who does not perform (the rite). Neither Mantras nor all the medicinal herbs, neither black magic nor secular rites, neither holy rites nor the Vedas, nor the two systems of Mīmāṃsā are capable of understanding īśvara. He can be known only through unswerving devotion. By calmness and great contentment, Sadāśiva should (i.e. could) be known.

column1: tena sarvaṃ saṃbhavaṃti sukhaduḥjhakhātmakaṃ jagat | paraṃtu saṃvadiṣyāmi kāryākāryavivakṣayā || 23 ||
column2: 23. It is through him that the entire universe with happiness and misery as its characteristic features, takes its origin. But I shall speak further with a desire to explain (what are the) right and wrong actions.

column1: tvamiṃdra bāliśo bhūtvā lokapālaiḥ sahādya vai | āgato bāliśo bhūtvā idānīṃ kiṃ kariṣyasi || 24 ||
column2: 24. O Indra, you have been foolish in accompanying the (other) guardians of the worlds here. What can you do further now with the self-same folly?

column1: ete rudrasahāyāśca gaṇāḥ paramaśobhanāḥ | kupitāśca mahābhāgā na tu śeṣaṃ prakurvate || 25 ||
column2: 25. These extremely splendid Gaṇas, the assistants of Rudra, have become infuriated. Those persons of exalted fortune cause nothing to be left over.

column1: evaṃ bṛhaspatervākyaṃ śrutvā te'pi divaukasaḥ | ciṃtāmāpedire sarve lokapālā maheśvarāḥ || 26 ||
column2: 26. On hearing these words of Bṛhaspati, all the heaven-dwellers and all those great gods, the guardians of the worlds, became anxious.

column1: tato'bravīdvīrabhadro gaṇaiḥ parivṛto bhṛśam | sarve yūyaṃ bāliśatvādavadānārthamāgatāḥ || 27 ||
column2: 27-28. Then Vīrabhadra who was very closely surrounded by the Gaṇas, said:

column1: avadānāni dāsyāmi tṛptyarthaṃ bhavatāṃ tvaran | evamuktvā śitairbāṇairjaghānātha ruṣānvitaḥ || 28 ||
column2: “On account of your ignorant nature, you have come here for the sake of Avadāna (glorious achievement). For the sake of your satisfaction, I shall immediately give you Avadānas (cutting into pieces).” After saying this, he furiously hit them with sharp arrows.

column1: tairbāṇairnihatāḥ sarve jagmuste ca diśo daśa || 29 ||
column2: 29. Hit by those arrows, all of them fled in all the ten directions.

column1: gateṣu lokapāleṣu vidruteṣu sureṣu ca | yajñavāṭe samāyāto vīrabhadro gaṇānvataḥ || 30 ||
column2: 30. When the guardians of the worlds had left the place and when the Devas had fled, Vīrabhadra came into the sacrificial enclosure accompanied by the Gaṇas.

column1: tadā ta ṛṣayaḥ sarve sarvameveśvareśvaram | vijñaptukāmāḥ sahasā ūcurevaṃ janārdanam || 31 ||
column2: 31. At that time all those sages who were desirous of intimating everything to Janārdana (Viṣṇu), the god of gods, said to him all at once:

column1: rakṣa yajñaṃ hi dakṣasya yajñosi tvaṃ na saṃśayaḥ | etacchrutvā tu vacanamṛṣīṇāṃ vai janārdanaḥ || 32 ||
column2: 32-33. “Protect the Yajña of Dakṣa. Indeed, there is no doubt that you are Yajña incarnate.”

column1: yoddhukāmaḥ sthito yuddhe viṣṇuradhyātmadīpakaḥ | vīrabhadro mahābāhuḥ keśavaṃ vākyamabravīt || 33 ||
column2: On hearing these words of the sages, Janārdana, the all-pervading lord, the illuminator of spiritual faculties, became desirous of fighting and stood there ready for the battle. Vīrabhadra of powerful arms spoke these words to Keśava (Viṣṇu):

column1: atra tvayāgataṃ kasmādviṣṇo vettrā mahābalam | dakṣasya pakṣamāśritya kathaṃ jeṣyasi tadvada || 34 ||
column2: 34. “Why have you come here, O Viṣṇu, you who know the great strength (of mine)? How will you be victorious by taking up Dakṣa’s side? Tell me that.

column1: dākṣāyaṇyā kṛtaṃ yacca na dṛṣṭaṃ kiṃ tvayānagha | tvaṃ cāpi yajñe dakṣasya avadānārthamāgataḥ | avadānaṃ prayacchāmi tava cāpi mahābhūja || 35 ||
column2: 35. Did you not observe? What has been done by Dākṣāyaṇī, O sinless one? You too have come for the sake of a share in the course of the Yajña of Dakṣa. O lord of powerful arms, I shall give oblation to you also.”

column1: evamuktvā praṇamyādau viṣṇuṃ sadṛśarūpiṇam | vīrabhadro'grato bhūtvā viṣṇuṃ vākyamathābravīt || 36 ||
column2: 36. After saying this, at the very outset, he bowed down to Viṣṇu whose form was similar to his. Vīrabhadra then went in front of Viṣṇu and spoke these words:

column1: yathā śaṃbhustathā tvaṃ hi mama nāstyatra saṃśayaḥ | tathāpi tvaṃ mahābāho yoddhukāmo'grataḥ stitaḥ | neṣyāmyapunarāvṛttiṃ yadi tiṣṭhestvamātmanā || 37 ||
column2: 37. “You are to me just like Śaṃbhu.[3] There is no doubt about this. Still, O lord of powerful arms, you face me with a desire to fight. If you continue to stay here yourself, I shall give you liberation (Apunarāvṛtti).”

column1: tasya tadvacanaṃ śrutvā vīrabhadrasya dhīmataḥ | uvāca prahasandevo viṣṇuḥ sarveśvareśvaraḥ || 38 ||
column2: 38. On hearing those words of the intelligent Vīrabhadra lord Viṣṇu, the lord of all lords, said laughingly: Viṣṇu said:

column1: viṣṇuruvāca | rudratejaḥprasūtosi pavitro'si mahāmate | anena prārthitaḥ pūrvaṃ yajñārthaṃ ca punaḥ punaḥ || 39 || ahaṃ bhaktaparādhīnastathā so'pi maheśvaraḥ | tenaiva kāraṇenātra dakṣasya yajanaṃ prati || 40 || āgato'haṃ vīrabhadra rudrakopasamudbhava | ahaṃ nivārayāmi tvāṃ tvaṃ vā māṃ vinivāraya || 41 ||
column2: 39-41. O highly intelligent one, you are born of the splendour of Rudra. You are very pure and holy. I had been requested by this (Dakṣa) before repeatedly for attending this Yajña. I am subservient to my devotees. So also is the case of Maheśvara. It is for that reason that I have come to this sacrifice of Dakṣa, O Vīrabhadra, born of the wrath of Rudra. Either I shall restrain you or you shall restrain me.

column1: ityuktavati goviṃde prahasya sa mahābhujaḥ | praśrayāvanato bhūtvā idamāha janārdanam || 42 ||
column2: 42. When Govinda said this much, that (Vīrabhadra) of mighty arms laughed and after bowing down humbly said this to Janārdana (Viṣṇu):

column1: yathā śivastathā tvaṃ hi yathā tvaṃ ca tathā śivaḥ | sevakāśca vayaṃ sarve tava vā śaṃkarasya ca || 43 ||
column2: 43. “Just as Śiva, so also you. Just as you, so also Śiva. All of us are servants both of you and of Śaṅkara.”

column1: tacchrutvā vacanaṃ tasya so'cyutaḥ saṃprahasya ca | idaṃ viṣṇurmahāvākyaṃ jagāda parameśvaraḥ || 44 ||
column2: 44. On hearing his words, Acyuta, Viṣṇu, the greatest lord, spoke these important words laughingly:

column1: yodhayasva mahābāho mayā sārdhamaśaṃkitaḥ | tavāstraiḥ pūryamāṇo'haṃ gacchāmi bhavanaṃ svakam || 45 ||
column2: 45. “Fight with me unhesitatingly, O lord of powerful arms. I shall go to my own abode when I am surfeited with your arrows and missiles.”

column1: tathetyuktvā tu vīro'sau vīrabhadro mahābalaḥ | gṛhītvā paramāstrāṇi siṃhanādairjagarja ha || 46 ||
column2: 46. Saying “so be it”, Vīrabhadra, the hero of great strength, took up the greatest of his missiles and roared like a lion.

column1: viṣṇuścāpi mahāghoṣaṃ śaṃkhanādaṃ cakāra saḥ | tacchrutvā ye gatā devā raṇaṃ hitvā'yayuḥ punaḥ || 47 ||
column2: 47. Viṣṇu too blew his conch of loud report. On hearing it, those Devas who had fled away from the battlefield, returned once again.

column1: vyūhaṃ cakrustadā sarve lokapālāḥ savāsavāḥ | tadendreṇa hato naṃdīvajreṇa śataparvaṇā || 48 || naṃdīnā ca hataḥ śakrastriśūlena stanāṃtare | vāyunā ca hato bhṛṃgī bhṛṃgiṇā vāyurāhataḥ || 49 || śūlena sitadhāreṇa saṃnaddho daṇḍadhāriṇā | yamena saha saṃgrāmaṃ mahākālo balānvitaḥ || 50 ||
column2: 48-50. All the Guardians of the Quarters including Indra made an array (of their soldiers). Then Nandin was struck by Indra with his Vajra (thunderbolt) that had a hundred spikes. Śakra was hit in the middle of his chest by Nandin with his trident. Bhṛṅgī was struck by Vāyu and Vāyu was struck (in return) by Bhṛṅgī. Standing well prepared with his trident of sharp edge, Mahākāla, endowed with great strength, fought with Yama holding the heavy rod.

column1: kubereṇa ca saṃgamya kūṣmāṃḍānāṃ patiḥ svayam | varuṇena samaṃ yuddhaṃ muṃḍaścaiva mahābalaḥ || 51 || yuyudhe parayāśaktyā trailokyaṃ vismayanniva | nairṛtena samāgamya caṃḍaścabalavattaraḥ || 52 || yuyudhe paramāstreṇa nairṛtyaṃ ca viḍaṃbayan | yoginīcakrasaṃyukto bhairavo nāyako mahān || 53 ||
column2: 51-55. The lord of Kūṣmāṇḍas clashed with Kubera. Muṇḍa of great strength fought with Varuṇa. He fought with such a great strength as surprised the three worlds. The exceedingly powerful Caṇḍa clashed with Nirṛta and fought with a very great missile, mocking his demoniac nature. Bhairava, the great leader, accompanied by the circle of Yoginīs tore through all the Devas and drank their wonderful blood. All the Kṣetrapālas, Bhūtas, Pramathas, Guhyakas, Śākinīs, Ḍakinīs, the terrible nine Durgās, Yoginīs, Yātudhānīs, Kūṣmāṇḍakas and others roared, drank blood and devoured a lot of flesh.

column1: bhakṣyamāṇaṃ tadā sainyaṃ vilokya surarāṭsvayam | vihāya naṃdinaṃ paścādvīrabhadraṃ samākṣipat || 56 ||
column2: 56. On seeing that his army was being devoured, the king of Suras left Nandin behind and challenged Vīrabhadra.

column1: vīrabhadro vihāyaiva viṣṇuṃ devendramāsthitaḥ | tayoryuddhamabhūddhoraṃ budhāṃgārakayoriva || 57 ||
column2: 57. Leaving off Viṣṇu, Vīrabhadra engaged Devendra. The battle between them was as terrible as that between Mars and Mercury.

column1: vīrabhadraṃ yadā śakro haṃtukāmastvarānvitaḥ | tāvacchaṃkraṃ gajasthaṃ hi purayāmāsa mārgaṇaiḥ || 58 || vīrabhadro ruṣāviṣṭo durnivāryo mahābalaḥ | tadedreṃṇāhataḥ śīghraṃ vajreṇa śataparvaṇā || 59 || sagajaṃ ca savajraṃ ca vāsavaṃ grastumudyutaḥ | hāhākāro mahā nāsīdbhūtānāṃ tatra paśyatām || 60 ||
column2: 58-61. When Śakra was desirous of killing Vīrabhadra and hastily prepared for the same, Vīrabhadra became furious and filled Indra who was seated on his elephant, with a mass of arrows. The extremely mighty Vīrabhadra who was unrestrainable, was immediately struck by Indra with his Vajra of a hundred spikes. Then he (Vīrabhadra) attempted to swallow Indra along with his elephant and thunderbolt. All the Bhūtas who saw Vīrabhadra like that desirous of killing Indra, raised the loud shouts of “Hā-Hā” (Alas-AIas). Seeing Vīrabhadra desirous of killing Indra, Viṣṇu came there in a hurry and stood in front of Vīrabhadra.

column1: śakraṃ ca pṛṣṭhataḥ kṛtvā yodhayāmāsa vai tadā | vīrabhadrasya viṣṇośca yuddhaṃ paramabhūttadā || 62 ||
column2: 62. He pushed Śakra behind and fought with Vīrabhadra. The battle between them was very tough.

column1: śastrāstrairvividhākārairyodhayāmāsatustadā | punarnaṃdinamālokya śakro yuddha viśāradaḥ || 63 ||
column2: 63-64. They then fought with various kinds of weapons and missiles. Seeing Nandin once again, Śakra who was an expert in battle, engaged him in a tumultuous duel.

column1: dvaṃdvayuddhaṃ sutumulaṃ devānāṃ pramathaiḥ saha | pramathā mathitā devaiḥ sarve te prādravanraṇāt || 64 ||
column2: There was a great clash between Devas and Pramathas. Pramathas were smashed by Devas and all of them fled from the battle.

column1: gaṇānparāṅmukhāndṛṣṭvā sarve te vyādhayo bhṛśam | rudrakopātsamudbhūtā devāścāpi pradudruvuḥ || 65 ||
column2: 65. On seeing the Gaṇas turning their faces away (from the battle), all those (bacterial) ailments[4] that had originated from the fury of Rudra rushed against Devas.

column1: jvaraistu pīḍitāndevāndṛṣṭvā viṣṇurhasanniva | jīvagrāheṇa jagrāha devāṃstāṃśca pṛthakpṛthak || 66 ||
column2: 66. On seeing Devas afflicted with the fevers, Viṣṇu laughingly seized Devas alive separately.

column1: devāścinau tadāhūya vyādhīnhaṃtuṃ tadā bhṛtim | dadau tābhyāṃ prayatnena gaṇayitvā subuddhimān || 67 ||
column2: 67. He called Aśvinī Devas in order to quell the ailments. The highly intelligent (lord) made them carefully work out and consider the requisite nourishment (medicine) and sustenance, and gave the same to them.

column1: jvarāṃśca sannipātāṃśca anye bhūtadruhastadā | tānsarvānnigṛhītvātha aśvinau tau mudānvitau | vijvarānatha devāṃśca kṛtvā mumudatuściram || 68 ||
column2: 68. Aśvinī gods caught hold of the fevers and Sannipāta (fevers) as well as other inimical elements and quelled them. They joyously made Devas free from fever and rejoiced for a long time.

column1: tairjitaṃ yoginīcakraṃ bhairavaṃ vyākulīkṛtam | tīkṣṇāgraiḥ pātayāmāsuḥ śarairbhūtagaṇānapi || 69 ||
column2: 69. The Yoginī Cakra also was subdued by them. With sharp-pointed arrows, they toppled down Bhairava who was highly excited and felled the Gaṇas too.

column1: surairvidrāvitaṃ sainyaṃ vilokya patitaṃ bhuvi | vīrabhadro rupāviṣṭo viṣṇuṃ vacanamabravīt || 70 ||
column2: 70. On seeing his army routed by Suras and felled down by them, Vīrabhadra became furious and spoke these words to Viṣṇu:

column1: tvaṃ śūrosi mahābāho devānāṃ pālako hyasi | yudhyasva māṃ prayatnena yadi te matirīdṛśī || 71 ||
column2: 71. “You are a heroic warrior, O mighty one. Indeed you are the protector of Devas. If you think so, come on, fight with me strenuously.”

column1: ityuktvā taṃ samāsādya viṣṇuṃ sarveśvareśvaram | vavarṣa niśitairbāṇairvīrabhadro mahābalaḥ || 72 ||
column2: 72. After saying thus, Vīrabhadra of great strength, approached Viṣṇu, the lord of all lords, and showered him with sharp arrows.

column1: tadā cakreṇa bhagavānvīrabhadraṃ jaghāna saḥ | āyāṃtaṃ cakramālokya grasitaṃ tatkṣaṇācca tat || 73 ||
column2: 73. Then the lord attacked Vīrabhadra with his discus. On seeing the discus coming, it was instantaneously swallowed (by Vīrabhadra).

column1: grasitaṃ cakramālokya viṣṇuḥ parapuraṃjayaḥ | mukhaṃ tasya parāmṛjya viṣṇunodgilitaṃ punaḥ || 74 ||
column2: 74-75. On seeing that his discus was swallowed, Viṣṇu, the conqueror of the cities of his enemies, stroked and pressed his mouth. Thus the (discus) was caused to be spitted out by Viṣṇu.

column1: svacakramādāya mahānubhāvo divaṃ gato'tho bhuvanaikabhartā | jñātvā ca tatsarvamidaṃ ca viṣṇuḥ kṛtī kṛtaṃ duṣprasahaṃ pareṣām || 75 ||
column2: Taking his discus, Viṣṇu of exalted nature, the sole lord of the universe, went to heaven. On understanding everything that had been done and was unbearable to the enemies he became-satisfied (of having done his job). FOOTNOTES AND REFERENCES: This shows a stage of conflict between the traditional Vedic religion and Śaivism. Vedic tradition prohibited its followers from even speaking with the non-Vedic Śaivas and Pañcarātras. These Śāstras were regarded as authoritative so far as they are not opposed to the Vedas (Sūta-Saṃhitā IV.4.16-18). Pārijāta as quoted in the Kṛtyaratnākara (p. 37) states the view of the mediaeval writers on Dharma Śāstra as follows:

column1: lomaśa uvāca | viṣṇau gate tadā sarve devāśca ṛṣibhiḥ saha | vinirjitā gaṇaiḥ sarve ye ca yajñopajīvinaḥ || 1 ||
column2: An imaginative precursor of modern bacterial warfare?[Sanskrit text for this chapter is available] Lomaśa continued: 1. When Viṣṇu went away, all those Devas along with the sages and all those who subsisted on that Yajña were totally vanquished by the Gaṇas.

column1: bhṛguṃ ca pātayāmāsa smaśrūṇāṃ luṃcanaṃ kṛtam | dvijāṃścotpāṭayāmāsa pūṣṇo vikṛtavikriyān || 2 ||
column2: 2. He (Vīrabhadra) made Bhṛgu fall down and his beard and moustache were plucked and cut.[1] He got the teeth of Pūṣan uprooted after distorting and deforming them.

column1: viḍaṃbitā svadhā tatra ṛṣayaśca viḍaṃbitāḥ | vavṛṣuste purīṣeṇa vitānāgnau rupānvitāḥ || 3 ||
column2: 3. Svadhā was ridiculed and the sages were mocked there. In their fury, they showered the sacrificial fire with faecal matter.

column1: anirvācyaṃ tadā cakrurgaṇāḥ krodhasamanvitāḥ | aṃtarvedyaṃtaragato dakṣo vai mahato bhayāt || 4 ||
column2: 4. The Gaṇas who had become excessively infuriated created unspeakable havoc. Out of great fear, Dakṣa hid himself beneath the altar.

column1: taṃ nilīnaṃ samājñāya ānināyaruṣānvitaḥ | kapoleṣu gṛhītvā taṃ khaḍgenopahataṃ śiraḥ || 5 ||
column2: 5. After realizing that he was in hiding, he angrily dragged him out. Holding by the cheeks, he struck his head with a sword.

column1: abhedyaṃ tacchiro matvā vīrabhadraḥ pratāpavān | skaṃdhaṃ padbhyāṃ samākramya kadhare'pīḍayattadā || 6 ||
column2: 6. Thinking that the head could not be pierced or split through, the valorous Vīrabhadra pressed the shoulder down with his feet and wrung the neck.

column1: gaṃdharātpāṭyamānācca śiraśchinnaṃ durātmanaḥ | dakṣasya ca tadā tena vīrabhadreṇa dhīmatā | tacchiraḥ suhutaṃ kuṃḍe jvali || 7 ||
column2: 7. On being wrenched off from the neck, the head of the vicious Dakṣa was taken away by the intelligent Vīrabhadra and thrown (lit. offered as oblation) into the blazing sacrificial pit instantaneously.

column1: ye cānya ṛṣayo devāḥ pitaro yakṣarākṣasāḥ | gaṇairupadrutāḥ sarve palāyanaparā yayuḥ || 8 ||
column2: 8. Other sages, Devas, Pitṛs, Yakṣas and Rākṣasas who yet stayed on were assaulted by the Gaṇas. All of them fled from the place.

column1: caṃdrādityagaṇāḥ sarve grahanakṣatratārakāḥ | sarve vicalitā hyāsangaṇaistepi hyupadrutāḥ || 9 ||
column2: 9. The Moon, the groups of Ādityas, all the Planets, Stars and Constellations—all of them were displaced and shaken. They too were attacked by the Gaṇas.

column1: satyalokaṃ gato brahmā putraśokena pīḍitaḥ | ciṃtayāmāsa cāvyagraḥ kiṃ kāryaṃ kāryamadya vai || 10 ||
column2: 10. Brahmā returned to Satyaloka. He was afflicted with sorrow for his son. He thought without being perturbed: ‘What action is to be taken now?’

column1: manasā dūyamānena śaṃna lebhe pitāmahaḥ | jñātvā sarvaṃ prayatnena duṣkṛtaṃ tasya pāpinaḥ || 11 || gamanāya matiṃ cakre kailāsaṃ parvataṃ prati | haṃsārūḍho mahātejāḥ sarvadevaiḥ samanvitaḥ || 12 ||
column2: 11-15. As his mind was suffering, the grandfather of the worlds did not derive any happiness. With great effort, he understood all the wicked deeds of that sinner. He decided to go to the Kailāsa mountain.

column1: praviṣṭaḥ parvataśreṣṭhaṃ sa dadarśa sadāśivam | ekāṃtavāsinaṃ rudraṃ śailādena samanvitam || 13 ||
column2: Hiding on his swan, accompanied by all the Devas, the lord of great splendour reached the most excellent mountain. There he saw Śiva, Rudra, accompanied by only Nandin, staying alone.

column1: kaparddinaṃ śriyā yuktaṃ vedāṃgānāṃ ca durgamam | tathāvidhaṃ samālokya brahma kṣobhaparo'bhavat || 14 ||
column2: He had matted hair and possessed great splendour. It was the lord who could not he grasped by the Vedas or their Aṅgas (Ancillaries). On seeing such a lord, Brahmā became greatly agitated.

column1: daṃḍavatpatito bhūmaukṣamāpayitumudyataḥ | saṃspṛśaṃ statpadābjaṃ ca caturmukuṭakoṭibhiḥ | stutiṃ kartuṃ samārebhe śivasya paramātmanaḥ || 15 ||
column2: He prostrated himself on the ground like a staff and began to plead for pardon, touching his lotus-like feet with the tips of the four crowns. He began to eulogize Śiva, the supreme soul.

column1: brahmovāca | namo rudrāya śāṃtāya brahmaṇe paramātmane | tvaṃ hi viśvasṛjāṃ sraṣṭā dhātā tvaṃ prapitāmahaḥ || 16 ||
column2: Brahmā said: 16. Obeisance to Rudra, the quiescent Brahman, the supreme soul. You are the creator and sustainer (protector) of the universe; you are the great-grandfather (of the world).

column1: namo rudrāya mahate nīlakaṃṭhāya vedhase | viśvāya viśvabījāya jagadānaṃdahetave || 17 ||
column2: 17. Obeisance to the great Rudra, to the blue-throated one, to the creator, to the lord identical with the universe, to the seed of the universe, to the cause of the bliss of the worlds.

column1: oṃkārastvaṃ vaṣaṭkāraḥ sarvāraṃbhapravartakaḥ | yajñosi yajñakarmāsi yajñānāṃ ca pravartakaḥ || 18 || sarveṣāṃ yajñakartṝṇāṃ tvameva pratipālakaḥ | śaraṇyosi mahādeva sarveṣāṃ prāṇināṃ prabho | rakṣa rakṣa mahādeva putraśokena pīḍitam || 19 ||
column2: 18-19. You are Oṃkāra; you are Vaṣaṭkāra, the prompter of the functioning of all enterprises. You are Yajña; you are the Yājñic rite. You are the cause of the functioning of Yajña; you alone are the protector of all the performers of sacrifice. You are worthy of being the refuge, O great lord, to all living beings. Save me, save me, O lord Mahādeva, I have been afflicted with the grief for my son.

column1: mahādeva uvāca | śrṛṇuṣvāvahito bhūtvā mama vākyaṃ pitāmaha | dakṣasya yajñabhaṃgoyaṃ na kṛtaśca mayā kvacit || 20 ||
column2: Mahādeva said: 20. O grandfather, listen attentively to my words. The destruction of the Yajña of Dakṣa has Dot been carried out by me at all.
